Finding Aid for
Arthur Dunham Papers, ca. 1900-1980

Finding aid prepared by:
Bentley Historical Library staff.

did.physloc: Portions of the collection are located offsite; two days notice required for retrieval.
did.abstract: Social worker in Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, professor of community organization at the University of Michigan, a pacifist imprisoned as a conscientious objector during World War I, a founding member of Ann Arbor Society of Friends. Papers include correspondence, subject files and research material relating to his work and teaching, files assembled for a history of the Ann Arbor Friends Meeting, material on his pacifist activities and published and unpublished writings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Arthur Dunham and came to the library in two major accessions, 1973 and 1980. Donor no. 5344

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research. In 1973, Arthur Dunham stipulated that the names of individuals used in his World War I reminiscences could not be cited.

userestrict.p: In 1973, Arthur Dunham signed a deed of gift transferring his copyright to the Regents of the University of Michigan. In 1981 following the death of Arthur Dunham and the receipt of additional materials, the Dunham daughter, Mrs. Ruth Hammarstrom, signed a deed of gift reserving literary rights to quotations totaling more than a 1000 words during her lifetime.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no.,Arthur Dunham Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Arthur Dunham was born in St. Louis, Missouri, on August 3, 1893. He graduated from Washington University in St. Louis in 1914, and obtained an M.A. in political science from the University of Illinois in 1917. Dunham started as a social worker in 1915 at a neighborhood center in St. Louis. Later in 1917, he became a family case worker for the St. Louis Provident Association.

Dunham's career was interrupted in 1918 as a result of America's entry into World War I. Dunham was a religious pacifist and refused service when drafted in July 1918. Incarcerated at Fort Riley until his court-martial on November 12, 1918, Dunham was sentenced to 25 years of hard labor. He remained in prison at Fort Leavenworth until his sentence was overturned on January 27, 1919. On May 31, 1919, Dunham married Esther Schneider, who had strongly influenced him to take his stand as a conscientious objector.

From September 1919 to May 1923, Dunham worked as secretary of the Philadelphia Social Service Exchange. From 1923 to 1925, he was secretary of the Newton (Massachusetts) Central Council, an organization of social agencies. In 1925 he became secretary of the Child Welfare Division of the Public Charities Association of Pennsylvania. He remained in this position until 1935. He also held temporary positions during this period with the Pittsburgh Child Welfare Study, the Family Welfare Association, and the Pennsylvania State Emergency Relief Board.

Dunham was appointed professor of community organization at the University of Michigan in 1935, holding this post until his retirement in 1963. At the university, Dunham taught courses in community organization and social welfare administration. From 1962 to 1972 he held posts as a visiting professor at a number of universities. In 1956 he made a trip through Europe and Asia, spending three months in India where he studied their community development programs. Dunham also made a trip to Northern Ireland in 1971 to serve as a consultant to the Northern Ireland Community Relations Commission.

Arthur and Esther Dunham joined the Society of Friends in 1923. In 1935 they were instrumental in founding the Ann Arbor Friends Meeting. They remained very active in the Meeting, and in 1975 Dunham wrote a history of its first forty years.

scopecontent.p: The Arthur Dunham papers are a valuable source for the study of the evolution of social work theory and practice, particularly in the area of community development and organization. In addition, the collection details Dunham's experience as a World War I conscientious objector, as well as including much information on the Ann Arbor Friends Meeting.

scopecontent.p: The Biographical and Autobiographical Material series, in addition to vita of both Arthur and Esther Dunham, includes a set of the family Christmas letters written over the period of 1923 to 1980 and an extensive manuscript entitled "Our Family" by Esther Dunham.

did.unittitle: Autobiographical sketch of Arthur and Esther Dunham
Esther S. Dunham Vita and biographical material

scopecontent.p: Although the nature of most series are clear from the title given them, others require explanation. The series labeled Rosters documents Dunham's activities from the 1920s through the 1970s. "Rosters" is the term used by Dunham, and in this series, he placed correspondence, memos, reports, and ephemera. Significantly, from the 1950s to his death, the "Roster" series was almost exclusively correspondence. The researcher should thus note that for this period the roster files are a more complete series of correspondence than the Correspondence series itself. The Rosters series is made up of a chronologically arranged subseries as well as separate subseries of "Rosters" relating to various posts Dunham held as visiting professor.

The Correspondence series, as noted, should be used with the Rosters series for Dunham correspondence. The series includes a chronological subseries dated 1915 to 1980 and two alphabetical subseries dated 1958 to 1978.

did.unittitle: On receiving position at University of Michigan 1935
On retirement from the University of Michigan 1962

scopecontent.p: The Ann Arbor Friends Meeting series contains two subseries. The first contains general materials relating to the Meeting. The second is a subject file of materials assembled by Dunham for his history of the Meeting.

did.unittitle: "Growth of a Friend's Meeting" by Esther Dunham
Dunham's History of Ann Arbor Friends Meeting
"Ann Arbor Friends Meeting: 1935-1975" by Arthur Dunham

scopecontent.p: The Society of Friends series contains material relating to Friends activities on the regional and national levels.

The Associations series includes very detailed chronological records of the activities of the Newton Central Council and the Public Charities Association (PCA) of Pennsylvania during Dunham's tenure with these organizations. The Newton Central Council case record is arranged by page number and accessible by a table of contents. The PCA material includes two principal subseries, one including minutes, reports, and agenda and the other including scrapbooks assembled by Dunham which reflect the activities of the PCA. Both of these subseries are arranged by date.

Also notable in the Associations series is the National Association of Social Workers material. This includes transcripts of an oral history interview with Dunham that includes extensive biographical and organizational information. Also within this series is a file for the Michigan Council of Churches Committee on Race Relations with material dating from 1943 to 1945 which may be of interest to students of early approaches to civil rights.

did.unittitle: Scrapbooks of Public Charities Association Materials (in folders)
Association for the Study of Community Organization
Michigan Welfare and Relief Study Commission 1936-1937
Michigan Welfare and Relief Study Commission report
Joint Vocational Service, Vocational Service for Social Workers Report 1939
American Association of Schools of Social Work 1943
Michigan Council of Churches, Committee on Race Relations
Ann Arbor Council of Social Agencies Self evaluations 1949-1950
University of Missouri Center for Community Development 1964

scopecontent.p: The Agency Studies series includes reports and other documentation about surveys and studies in which Dunham participated or in which he was interested. Prominent in this series are the Pittsburgh Child Welfare Study, 1929-1930 and a study undertaken for the Welfare Council of New York City in 1948.

did.unittitle: Welfare Council of New York City 1948
Women's International League for Peace and Freedom 1955

scopecontent.p: Course Outlines have arranged by course topic and them chronologically. This series should be used jointly with the following series for documentation of the content of Dunham courses.

odd.p: (different course numbers; some gaps in dates)

scopecontent.p: The series labeled Community Development was organized by Dunham into subseries reflecting the use which he made of these materials. The series includes a subject file subseries apparently used by Dunham for his personal reference and a course subseries with information about the courses Dunham taught in this area.

did.unittitle: Missouri, University of, AID African Program

scopecontent.p: The series labeled Community Organization was organized by Dunham into subseries reflecting the use which he made of these materials. The series includes a subject file subseries apparently used by Dunham for his personal reference and a course subseries with information about the courses Dunham taught in this area.

The series labeled Social Welfare Administration was organized by Dunham into subseries reflecting the use which he made of these materials. The series includes a subject file subseries apparently used by Dunham for his personal reference and a course subseries with information about the courses Dunham taught in this area.
Public Welfare is similar to the preceding three series, though much smaller. It includes course outlines, lecture notes, teaching materials, and other papers.

The Conscientious Objection series includes detailed diaries and correspondence principally covering Dunham's incarceration during World War I. In addition, it includes an unpublished manuscript describing Dunham's experiences during this period and various pamphlets published in support of conscientious objection.

did.unittitle: "Narrative of a Conscientious Objector" by Arthur Dunham (manuscript)
List of World War I Conscientious Objectors
"Army Casework and a Military Heretic" by Dunham (manuscript)
"Record of Trial by General Court of William Arthur Dunham"
Newspaper and magazine accounts of Fort Leavenworth strike
Correspondence re effort to publish "Narrative of a Conscientious Objector."

scopecontent.p: The Travel series covers Dunham's trip abroad in 1956 and his work in Northern Ireland in 1971. It also includes extensive field notes on community development in India.

did.unittitle: "Community Development in Northern Ireland" by Hywel Griffiths

scopecontent.p: A smaller series - Work Reports - is dated 1953 to 1964.
Social Work-Social Welfare includes speeches and articles about these topics.

did.unittitle: Curtis Osborn/Jane Wayland Children's Home, Phoenix, Az.

scopecontent.p: The Curtis Osborn-Jane Wayland Children's Home series contains an extremely detailed diary compiled by Osborn describing his running of the Jane Wayland Children's Home in Phoenix, Arizona from 1947 to 1950. This project was apparently under Dunham's guidance.
Topical Files is a series maintained by Dunham consisting of both personal and collected material on subjects of interest to the Dunhams.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor-Survey of Social Welfare Program 1940
College records of Arthur and Esther Dunham
George Batten Advertising Company, Employment with 1913-1914
High school records of Arthur Dunham
Marriage of Arthur and Esther Dunham
National Association of Social Workers. Neighborhood Action Project 1966
National Conference of Social Work Report 1940
"Research in Social Welfare: Proposed Program for U.M.," 1954

scopecontent.p: Within Unpublished Manuscripts, the researcher will find childhood and college writings of Dunham, his master's these on Progressive Party of 1912, a chronological run of unpublished papers, and a study entitled, "Public Relief in Three Michigan Counties."

did.unittitle: "Case Problems in Community Organization and Social Welfare Administration," 1955

scopecontent.p: The Published Material series begins with a "Scrapbooks of Published Material" assembled by Dunham and including most of his publications from 1916 to 1978. The arrangement is basically chronological, and each document is numbered. This subseries is preceded by an index listing material by document number, subject, and title. The subseries following the Scrapbooks contain published material not included in the scrapbooks. The series also includes published books and articles of Dunham.

scopecontent.p: Photographs includes portraits, family photos, and photos relating to his work, including Social Service Exchanges (1920s) and community development seminars (1950s and 1960s). There are also photos of a World War I conscientious objector prison camp at Fort Douglas, Utah, and photos of an Ann Arbor Friends meeting.

did.unittitle: Fort Douglas, Utah, C.O. Prison Camp 1919-1920
